To these were added olians; the Methymneans, for instance, who were to furnish shipping, but were exempted from tribute; the Tene- dians, farther, and nians, who were tributaries: But these, being olians, were now compelled to fight a- gainst other olians; namely, their own founders, the B otians, who adhered to the Syracusans. The Pla- t ans. did the same, and were the only B otians that acted against B otians upon the justisiable pretext of las- ting enmity. The Rhodians, farther, and Cytherians, attended, though both of Doric descent: The Cythe- rians, truly, who are a Laced monian colony, bore arms at this juncture on the Athenian side, against the Laced monians under the command of Gylippus and the Rhodians, Argives by descent, were obliged to turn their arms against the Doric Syracusans; nay, a- gainst the Geloans, a colony of their own, now acting in concert with the Syracusans. Of the people of the lfles on the coast of Peloponnesus came the Cephallenians and Zacynthians independent in fact, but through their situation controuled in some measure by the Athe- nians, who are masters of the sea. The Corcyreans, farther, who were not only of Doric, bur, what is more, were even of Corinthian, original, as being a colony of the latter, and by blood allied to the former, from compul- sion, as they gave out for a colour, though in truth from deliberate malice, since opposing the Corinthians, whom they hated, followed the Athenians with an ar- dour inferior to none. The Messenians also, now stiled Meflenians of Naupactus, and those from Pylus, which was still held by the Athenians, were brought along to the war; to whom must be added a small party of Me- garean exiles, who by a sad reverse of fortune now took part against the Selinuntians, who were also Megarean.
